physDesc.p: This letter is four pages long. The word “Aldington” is written in pencil in the top left corner of the first page, slanting up from left to right. The second page has “R.A.--2” in the top left and the date in the top right.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: Your letter of June 11th has come, and I am awfully glad to know that you like the Anthology. I think it is good this year.

It is an awful feeling to me to know that you are really in the army. Of course, I cannot bear to have your brains and beautiful imagination knocked here and there in the rough duties of a private soldier’s life. But after all, poetry must be real if it is anything. We who write it must be virile, and capable of translating it into life when necessary and taking the drudgery merely as we take the drudgery of our art. This sounds sententious, but how difficult it is to say the things one means without sounding sententious! But you will see what I mean, and after all, it is a splendid experience, which will enlarge not only your outlook on life but your suggestions for poetry.

The new poems you sent I think are perfectly beautiful, particularly “Spring Moods,” “Images,” and the one to Hilda’s work. I instantly rang Braithwaite up on the telephone and offered them to him, as his magazine already has a much larger circulation than Harriet’s. They sold 2600 copies on the newsstands alone of their second number. His judgement as an editor is very bad, but through his genuine interest in the subject and his desire to help poets, he manages to get in some good things, by a fluke as it were. He was perfectly delighted with these poems of yours and asked me to send them over to him at once, and he will certainly take some of them, if not all. I do not think I shall let him take all; I think it would be better to let Harriet have some; but she is very difficult to manage these days, now that Alice Henderson has left. I am beginning to think that Alice Henderson was the balance-wheel of that magazine, and that all the good things were owning to her influence. She got little or no credit, poor girl, but now that she has had to go to New Mexico with consumption and give up her work, I can see the difference in the way the magazine is run – more prejudice, more reactionaryism, more admiration of youthful immigrants with very little talent who have imposed upon Harriet, like Michaelson. Also, as we know, Harriet keeps poems so long, whereas Braithwaite publishes his very soon, so I hope you will think I did right to give Braithwaite his choice.

The Anthology seems to be doing fairly well. A thousand copies were printed of the first edition, of which 750 were bound. Of these 750, only 225 were still in the publisher’s hands about two weeks ago. I rang them up to-day over the telephone to get the latest news for you, but the partners were all out at a meeting, so this is my latest bulletin.

I sent you some reviews a day or two ago. They are not any great shakes, as you see, but we have a slight one, and not at all a bad one, appearing in the July “Poetry Review,” written by Professor William Lyon Phelps of Yale. Professor Phelps is more sympathetic than profound in some ways; his great subject is Browning, but in erudite circles, he is considered a bit sketchy. He is immensely popular, however, and the lectures which he gave at the Lowell Institute for my brother last Winter had to be repeated, they were so jammed. Therefore, to have him review us is distinctly a good thing for us.

I have just received a letter from William Carlos Williams, asking me to send something for the August number of “Others.” But as I wrote you in the Winter, Fletcher and I decided not to contribute to that periodical, so I was obliged to refuse; but I am sorry, for I like Williams.

Imagism is fast ceasing to be a freak subject over here and is beginning to be treated with respect; people are fast getting inoculated, and I think a few years more we can feel that we have really succeeded. It amuses me very much when I think how Ezra sneered that, without him, we should go under.

Brown promised to give me a new instalment on his debt to you today, but it has not yet appeared. I shall hold this letter over until to-morrow and see if I cannot collect it. Certainly to get money out of that man is like wringing wine from a stone.

I had a couple of letters from Fletcher by the same mail which brought yours. He is at his old quarters in Sydenham (37 Crystal Palace Park Road). Perhaps by this time you will have seen him. Can he not come and see you at the camp, even if you are no longer a civilian? And, Richard, why don’t you apply for work as an interpreter? With your knowledge of French, and German, and Italian, you would be invaluable to them; and to waste that knowledge as a private is plain silly. Do see if you cannot do something about it, for I know that interpreters are wanted, as I hear so constantly.

I have sent both our Anthologies to Mr. Sanborn, who does the American chronicle in the “Mercure de France,” you remember, and who asked to see them; and he says he shall mention them again in his Autumn “chronique.”

Do not worry about Mrs. Untermeyer’s poem! I understand perfectly how it is. I dished myself with Miss Weaver last year when I told her frankly what I thought of Miss Marsden’s articles, and you can hardly expect either of those ladies to look upon me with favour. I have no doubt at all that it is Ezra’s influence that has caused the coolness toward you; but I think it will not be long before you do not need “The Egoist.” My very good friend Braithwaite stepped in and saved me by instantly accepting that poem for the “Poetry Review,” so that in writing to Jean Untermeyer I merely substitute one paper for the other; and she is, on the whole, the gainer, as the “Poetry Review” pays.

Braithwaite has asked me to tell you that he hopes you will accept the position of foreign correspondent when you are mustered out; and I am sure that if you want to send him anything, either poetry or an article, at any time from the front, he will receive it gladly and will remit to Hilda. You can either send them to me, and I will send them on to him, or you can write to him direct; William Stanley Braithwaite, 27 Ellsworth Avenue, Cambridge, Mass.

I gave both our anthologies to a friend of mine the other day, a lady who has never read poetry in her life before to any extent, because she never cared for it and preferred to read novels. You will perceive by this that she is not a literary person and only read for the human interest. She has now abandoned novels completely and is absolutely drowned in poetry. She wrote me to-day and said: “The Imagists have caught me.” To be sure, she is a little mixed, and considers all modern poets of any vitality Imagists – a sort of generic title in her mind for all that is good and vital in verse. She was so overcome and upset by your “Childhood” that she said: “Is there nothing I can do for that man? I can’t bear to think of the loneliness of that childhood, and it makes me feel that I should like to meet him.” I said I thought what she could do would be to talk about you early and late; and possible sometime, if we are all in London, I will arrange a meeting between her and you and Hilda.

I think Hilda’s things in the new Anthology are perfectly beautiful. I read them again and again and never tire of them, and I quite agree with you that “Midday” following the sea things is a magnificent contrast. I will try to write very often while you are gone both to you and to Hilda, whether I get any answers or not. Neither war nor trenches shall interfere with the great strong Imagist band which stretches between us. It has been a real brotherhood, hasn’t it? And we can all feel, I think, that it has given us something of the same quality towards each other that comrades in arms used to have in the old days.
body.closer: Good luck to you, Dear Boy, and write when you can.

div.note: Most likely Max Michelson (1880-1953), a Lithuanian immigrant who published poetry and reviews for Poetry.
